snippet: The generals wanted to make sure that their ability to control politics was written into the Constitution, the judge said, even as they promised to hand authority to elected leaders.
abstract: Tahani el-Gebali, judge who acts as deputy president of Egypt's Supreme Constitutional Court, reveals that she advised the country's generals not to cede authority to civilians until a Constitution was written and to block the rise of Islamists in the newly-democratic country; court was instrumental in allowing the military to dissolve the first fairly elected Parliament in Egypt’s history.
lead_paragraph: The generals wanted to make sure that their ability to control politics was written into the Constitution, the judge said, even as they promised to hand authority to elected leaders.

headline.main: Judge Helped Egypt’s Military to Cement Power
headline.print_headline: Judge Helped Egypt’s Military to Cement Power
